intro: Oxytropis leucocyanea, commonly known as white locoweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its legume fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has small, compound leaves with a hairy texture. Its flowers are usually pale blue to white, and it produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. Oxytropis leucocyanea is notable for its ability to thrive in arid environments and its role in supporting local ecosystems.
